content:
The artistic styles of Renaissance and Baroque art are characterized by highly realistic and detailed depictions of subjects, often with religious or mythological themes. The use of light and shadow was also very important in these styles, with artists using techniques such as chiaroscuro to create the appearance of three-dimensional space on a two-dimensional surface.

In contrast, Impressionism and Post-Impressionism are characterized by looser brushstrokes, a focus on capturing the fleeting moments of daily life, and a rejection of traditional techniques of perspective and composition. Impressionist painters placed a strong emphasis on the effects of light and color, while Post-Impressionist painters experimented with new forms of expression like pointillism and a more abstract use of color and line.

Overall, the Renaissance and Baroque styles were more focused on realistic depictions of classical subjects, while Impressionism and Post-Impressionism placed more emphasis on capturing the fleeting moments of everyday life and experimenting with new forms of artistic expression.
